They are already well-adapted to their surroundings.

 One want an organism can change is due to being in a different environment, isolated from the previous group. Mutations can occur, and if they aren't killer, they are passed on. Changes in genetic material through mutation add to the gene pool and are passed on through mating.

 Look, I think we're getting confused here, let me try to clarify my position and see where that takes us. Like I said before God is unfalsifiable, is there a superme being who started everything, who set up the laws of nature and works through them? I don't know, and since there is no way science can test for this, science can't prove or disprove His existance, God is neutral to science. Many astronomers who accept the Big Bang are Christians, many biologists who accept evolution are Christians, many geologists who accept an old earth are Christians. That's their (and your) right. I don't say science disproves God.
 But since I don't see any evidence FOR God, I'm skeptical, maybe He's there and maybe He's not. I certainly don't look down on those who have greater faith than me.
 But what we can use science for is to disprove some of the myths some Christians have based on a strictly literal reading of the Bible. The earth and the universe is only 6000 years old? Well, all the evidence, like radiometric dating, sedimentation rates, physics, says it's old, roughly 4.5 billion years old. With this model of an old earth, we can make successful predictions, like where certain fossils will be found, where oil fields will be found, where coal deposits will be found, and so far, these predictions have been correct. A reasonable person would have to conclude that yes, the earth is old, not that there is no God. The same with the theory of evolution, a reasonable person looking at the overwhelming evidence objectively would have to conclude that that's how life developed. Now COULD an all powerful, magical entity have supernaturally created everything the way it is by going beyond the natural laws? Yeah, if such a being exists and if this being is omnipotent, then i guess it is a possiblity. Those are 2 big "if's" and we have no evidence for either, but this would be outside of the scientific method because science can only examine the natural world. And if God really did work like that, it seems very deceptive, to have a universe that has every appearence of being billions of years old, a planet with every appearence of being over 4 billion years old and life giving every appearence of evolving. Also, if God supernaturally set it up to appeaar that way, shouldn't we examine it that way and draw those conclusions from the evidence God gave us? 
 On the flip side, science looks for the most parsimonious explainations, explainations that require the least assumptions. If certain radioactive isotopes have half lives of billions of years, why shouldn't we conclude the earth is old? If mountains take 100s of thousands to millions of years to form, why shouldn't we conclude the earth is old?
